Sun, Mar 17, 2019 at 7:39 AM

Summary

Avoidance is the key to stay safe in the mountains today. It is getting harder for you to trigger an avalanche; however, if you do it will most likely be very large and inescapable. The only sure way to avoid large dangerous avalanches right now is to stick to lower angle slopes with no avalanche terrain above you. This means not traveling in avalanche runnouts or even timbered areas below avalanche starting zones. You can find safer riding options on wind-sheltered slopes less with a slope angle than 30 degrees without overhead hazard. If you do chose to move into steeper terrain, you need to understand that the weak layers are buried so deeply that you will not see signs of instability such as cracking or collapsing to help you make decisions. Digging down and looking or performing snowpack tests will give you little indication of the danger. There is no way to tell if a slope is safe right now it really comes down to your risk tolerance to where you choose to ride. Know that if you trigger an avalanche it will break deep, will break across terrain features, and will run to the valley floor.  

It will be a warm day with temperatures reaching into the low 30's near and below treeline. Watch for small wet avalanches running from steep rocky southerly-facing terrain. Most of these avalanches will be small, but they may grow large enough to knock you off your feet and push you someplace you don't want to be.

Whether you use the CAIC forecast every day or once a year, please consider becoming a Friend of CAIC by making a donation today. https://avalanche.state.co.us/donate/

What You Need to Know About These Avalanches


Deep Persistent Slab avalanches are destructive and deadly events that can release months after the weak layer was buried. They are scarce compared to Storm or Wind Slab avalanches. Their cycles include fewer avalanches and occur over a larger region. You can triggered them from well down in the avalanche path, and after dozens of tracks have crossed the slope. Avoid the terrain identified in the forecast and give yourself a wide safety buffer to address the uncertainty.

What You Need to Know About These Avalanches


Loose Wet avalanches occur when water is running through the snowpack, and release at or below the trigger point. Avoid very steep slopes and terrain traps such as cliffs, gullies, or tree wells. Exit avalanche terrain when you see pinwheels, roller balls, a slushy surface, or during rain-on-snow events.

Sun, Mar 17, 2019 at 7:56 AM
Issued by: Kreston Rohrig Statewide Weather Forecast  

This period of LOW-probability, HIGH-consequence avalanche activity is troublesome and scary. Stability is improving, and snowpack tests point to a stable snowpack, but if you look around at all the massive crowns and huge piles of debris, it's hard to feel super confident. There is no doubt that the likelihood of triggering one of these monsters is decreasing. Given the size and strength of the slab formed from March's snowfall, it will likely need a significant trigger to fail. This could come in the form of multiple snowmobiles on a slope, a large cornice fall, or even a huge impact from a cliff jump.  In any case, triggering or getting caught by one of these avalanches will be deadly. So what can you do? Well, terrain avoidance is always going to be the best medicine for managing these conditions. Keeping out of avalanche terrain and giving runout zones of larger slopes a wide-berth is the only real way to stay safe. It is hard to predict when this threat will quiet down or go away completely. You have to assess how much risk you and your group are willing to accept and if the reward is really worth it. 

The other consideration this weekend is warming temperatures. Massive cornices loom over many steep alpine slopes and could fail as they warm and weaken. A good example of this scenario played out on Vail Pass recently, as a giant chunk of cornice failed and triggered the slope below. Fortunately, overhanging cornices are easy to identify and avoid. The only challenge is knowing when they are going to fail and how big of an avalanche they will create. The second thing to watch for with warming slopes is wet avalanches. These will be on the smaller side but should be given consideration if you are traveling through wet, gloppy snow or start seeing pinwheels in steep rocky terrain. 

Bottom line, we are all still a little shaken by the recent avalanche cycle and continued activity. Keeping a conservative mindset and avoiding the temptation to ramp up your terrain choices will help reduce your risk of being caught in a bad situation.
